TP53 and RB1 are critical tumor suppressor genes that regulate cell growth, division, and death. RB1, or retinoblastoma 1, regulates cell cycle progression, controlling the transition from the G1 phase to the S phase to ensure that cells with damaged DNA do not proliferate. The inactivation or mutations in TP53 and RB1 have been associated with various types of cancer, including SCLC.

## Contribution of TP53 and RB1 Mutations to SCLC Initiation

Mutational events in TP53 and RB1 are significantly associated with the initiation of SCLC. In addition to TP53 and RB1, mutations in other tumor suppressor genes can also impact SCLC initiation and evolution. Understanding the impact of mutational events in other tumor suppressor genes on SCLC can provide valuable insights into the disease's biology and may lead to the development of more effective therapeutic strategies.

The interaction between TP53 and RB1 mutations and other tumor suppressor genes plays a crucial role in driving SCLC evolution.
